The humid air of Tallahassee clung to Spencer's skin like a damp shirt as he walked across the campus quad, his worn sneakers making soft sounds against the brick pathway. The late afternoon sun filtered through the canopy of oak trees, casting dancing shadows that seemed to mirror the restless feeling in his chest. At twenty-three, Spencer had grown accustomed to the weight of secrets, but some secrets felt heavier than others, especially when they involved matters of the heart.

"Spencer, wait up!" The familiar voice made him turn, and there was Jordan, jogging to catch up with that easy smile that had been Spencer's undoing since their freshman year. Jordan's dark hair was tousled from running, and his green eyes held that perpetual spark of mischief that Spencer had fallen in love with somewhere between late-night study sessions and early morning coffee runs.

"You're going to be late for your own graduation party," Jordan said, slightly breathless as he fell into step beside Spencer. Their friendship had been the most natural thing in the world, built on shared laughter, comfortable silences, and an understanding that went deeper than words. But for Spencer, it had become something more complicated, something that lived in the spaces between what was said and what remained carefully hidden.

"I'm not sure I'm in the mood for celebrating," Spencer replied, adjusting the strap of his messenger bag. The leather was worn smooth from years of use, a gift from his adoptive parents when he'd started college. They'd been supportive of his studies in literature, though Spencer sometimes caught them exchanging glances when they thought he wasn't looking, as if they were keeping their own secrets.

Jordan stopped walking and grabbed Spencer's arm gently. "Hey, what's going on? You've been weird all week. This is supposed to be our big moment – we made it through four years of college without killing each other or flunking out. That deserves at least a beer and some terrible karaoke."

Spencer looked at Jordan's hand on his arm and felt that familiar flutter in his stomach. How do you tell your best friend that somewhere along the way, friendship had transformed into something that kept you awake at night? How do you explain that every casual touch feels like electricity, that every laugh shared feels like a small piece of heaven, that you've been living with this secret love for so long it's become part of your DNA?

"It's nothing," Spencer lied, the words tasting bitter on his tongue. "Just thinking about what comes next, you know? Everything's changing."

Jordan's expression softened, and he moved his hand to Spencer's shoulder. "Change isn't always bad. Besides, we're not going anywhere. You're stuck with me, remember? We made a pact sophomore year – best friends for life, through thick and thin, through bad relationships and career disasters."

The mention of relationships sent a small stab through Spencer's heart. Jordan had dated casually throughout college, nothing serious, but each new person had been a reminder of what Spencer couldn't have. He'd become an expert at being the supportive friend, offering advice and listening to stories about dates while dying a little inside each time.

"Right," Spencer managed, forcing a smile. "The pact."

They resumed walking toward downtown Tallahassee, where their favorite bar was hosting what Jordan had dubbed their "freedom celebration." The streets were alive with the energy of a college town in late spring, students spilling out of restaurants and cafes, everyone seeming to move with purpose and excitement about the future. Spencer envied their certainty.

"You know what I was thinking about today?" Jordan said, his hands shoved deep in his pockets. "Remember freshman year when you got food poisoning from that sketchy taco truck, and I stayed up all night taking care of you? You were so embarrassed, kept apologizing for ruining my weekend."

Spencer remembered. He remembered Jordan bringing him ginger ale and sitting on the edge of his dorm room bed, talking quietly about everything and nothing while Spencer's stomach settled. He remembered thinking, even through the nausea, that this was what love felt like – not the dramatic, sweeping kind from movies, but the quiet, steady kind that showed up with medicine and stayed through the messy parts.

"I remember you making fun of me for being dramatic," Spencer said.

"I wasn't making fun of you. I was trying to distract you. There's a difference." Jordan bumped his shoulder against Spencer's. "That was when I knew we were going to be real friends. Not just dorm room proximity friends or study group friends, but the kind of friends who see each other at your worst and stick around anyway."

Spencer's chest tightened. Jordan meant it as a compliment, but it felt like a gentle reminder of the boundaries between them. Friends. Always friends.

The bar was crowded when they arrived, filled with familiar faces from their literature classes and a handful of people from Jordan's philosophy major. Spencer had always been more introverted, content to let Jordan be the social butterfly while he observed from the edges. Tonight felt no different, except for the underlying current of melancholy that Spencer couldn't shake.

"Spencer!" Lisa from their Victorian Literature seminar waved them over to a corner booth. "We saved you guys seats. Jordan said you might actually show up tonight instead of hiding in the library."

"Very funny," Spencer said, sliding into the booth. Jordan settled beside him, close enough that their thighs touched, and Spencer had to concentrate on not reading anything into the casual contact.

The conversation flowed around them – post-graduation plans, job prospects, speculation about professors they'd never have to see again. Spencer contributed when spoken to directly but found himself mostly listening, watching Jordan animated and happy, laughing at stories and adding his own. This was Jordan in his element, surrounded by people who enjoyed his company, unaware of the quiet intensity of Spencer's gaze.

"What about you, Spencer?" The question came from Mike, a guy from Jordan's philosophy classes who Spencer had never particularly warmed to. "Any big plans now that you're free from academic tyranny?"

"Teaching," Spencer said simply. "I start a graduate program in the fall, working toward becoming a professor."

"Following in someone's footsteps?" Mike asked, and something about his tone made Spencer look up sharply.

"Not really," Spencer replied carefully. "I just love literature. Want to share that with students someday."

Jordan jumped in, sensing Spencer's discomfort. "Spencer's going to be one of those professors students remember forever. The kind who actually makes you think about books instead of just memorizing themes for tests."

The warmth in Jordan's voice made Spencer's heart skip, but before he could respond, Jordan suddenly went pale and pressed a hand to his forehead.

"You okay?" Spencer asked immediately, his attention fully focused on his friend.

"Yeah, just... suddenly feel really hot. And my head is pounding." Jordan's voice sounded strained, different from his usual easy tone.

Spencer reached over and pressed the back of his hand to Jordan's forehead. Jordan's skin was burning up, fever heat that made Spencer's stomach drop with worry.

"You're burning up. We should get you home."Without waiting for Jordan's protest, Spencer was already sliding out of the booth, his protective instincts overriding any social awkwardness. He'd seen Jordan sick before, but this felt different – the sudden onset, the way Jordan's usually bright eyes had gone glassy and unfocused. The bar's noise and warmth suddenly felt oppressive, and Spencer could see that Jordan was struggling to maintain his composure in front of their friends.

"Come on," Spencer said quietly, offering his hand to help Jordan up. "Let's get you some air." Jordan accepted the help without his usual jokes about being babied, which worried Spencer even more. As they made their way through the crowded bar, Spencer kept one hand on Jordan's back, guiding him past groups of celebrating students and toward the door. The cool evening air hit them like a relief, and Jordan immediately leaned against the brick wall of the building, closing his eyes and taking deep breaths.

"This is weird," Jordan mumbled, his words slightly slurred. "I felt fine an hour ago, and now I feel like I got hit by a truck." He opened his eyes and looked at Spencer with an expression that was almost vulnerable. "Will you drive me home? I don't think I should be behind the wheel right now." Spencer nodded immediately, fishing Jordan's keys from his friend's jacket pocket when Jordan's hands shook too much to manage it himself.

The drive to Jordan's off-campus apartment was quiet except for Jordan's occasional directions and the soft sound of him breathing carefully through what was obviously a worsening headache. Spencer kept glancing over, noting the way Jordan had slumped against the passenger window, his usual animated energy completely drained. When they finally pulled into Jordan's parking lot, Spencer had to help him up the stairs to his second-floor apartment, Jordan leaning more heavily on him with each step. The physical closeness would have been intoxicating under different circumstances, but Spencer's worry overshadowed everything else.

"Okay, couch or bed?" Spencer asked once they were inside Jordan's familiar living space, though he was already guiding Jordan toward the bedroom. The apartment was typical college housing – mismatched furniture, textbooks scattered on every surface, and photos covering the walls that documented their four years of friendship. Spencer had been here countless times, but tonight it felt different, charged with an intimacy that came from taking care of someone you loved when they were vulnerable.

Jordan collapsed onto his bed fully clothed, curling up on his side with a soft groan. "Everything hurts," he said, his voice muffled by the pillow. "My head, my joints, even my skin feels weird." Spencer immediately went into caretaker mode, the same way he had freshman year during the food poisoning incident, but with more confidence now that came from years of knowing exactly how Jordan preferred to be cared for when he was sick.

He found the thermometer in Jordan's bathroom cabinet, along with fever reducers and a glass for water. Jordan's temperature was 102.3, high enough to be concerning but not immediately dangerous. Spencer made Jordan take the medication, then sat on the edge of the bed, unsure whether he should stay or go. The rational part of his mind said he should leave Jordan to rest, but everything else in him rebelled at the thought of leaving when Jordan was clearly miserable.

"Stay?" Jordan asked quietly, as if reading Spencer's internal debate. His eyes were closed, but his hand moved across the bedspread until it found Spencer's wrist. "I know it's stupid, but I always feel better when you're here when I'm sick. You're like a human security blanket or something." The request made Spencer's heart clench with a mixture of tenderness and longing. He wanted nothing more than to stay, to take care of Jordan through whatever this illness was, but he also knew how dangerous it was for his emotional equilibrium to be this close, this needed.

"Of course I'll stay," Spencer said, making the only choice he could. "Let me just text Lisa and tell them you're okay but heading home sick." Jordan's grip on his wrist relaxed, and Spencer could see some of the tension leave his friend's shoulders. Spencer quickly sent the text, then settled into the armchair next to Jordan's bed, close enough to monitor him but far enough away to maintain some emotional distance.

The next few hours passed in a haze of fever checks, water refills, and quiet conversation when Jordan was awake enough to talk. Spencer found himself studying Jordan's face in the dim light from the bedside lamp, noting details he'd memorized years ago but never allowed himself to really examine – the way Jordan's dark eyelashes cast shadows on his cheeks, the small scar above his left eyebrow from a childhood accident, the way his hair fell across his forehead when he wasn't conscious enough to push it back. It felt like a violation of their friendship to look so intently, but Spencer couldn't help himself.

Around midnight, Jordan woke up from a restless doze and found Spencer still in the chair, now reading one of Jordan's philosophy books by lamplight. "You don't have to stay up," Jordan said, his voice hoarse but clearer than it had been earlier. "I'm feeling a little better, I think. The headache isn't as bad." Spencer looked up from the book, relieved to see that Jordan's eyes looked more focused, though his cheeks were still flushed with fever.

"Your fever's down a little," Spencer confirmed after taking his temperature again. "But you're still running hot. How's everything else feeling?" Jordan shifted carefully, testing his joints and muscles, and Spencer tried not to read too much into the way Jordan's t-shirt had ridden up slightly, revealing a strip of skin that Spencer definitely should not be noticing while his friend was sick.

"Still achy, but not like I've been hit by a truck anymore. More like maybe just a bicycle," Jordan attempted a weak smile. "Thank you for staying. I know this isn't how you wanted to spend your graduation night." Spencer set the book aside and leaned forward slightly, his elbows on his knees. The truth was that there was nowhere else he'd rather be, no one else he'd rather be taking care of, but he couldn't say that without revealing too much.

"This is exactly where I want to be," Spencer said carefully, then added with forced lightness, "Besides, someone has to make sure you don't do anything stupid while you're fevered. Remember sophomore year when you had the flu and tried to go to class anyway? I found you passed out in the hallway of the literature building." Jordan laughed softly at the memory, and the sound made Spencer's chest warm with affection and relief that Jordan was feeling well enough to find things amusing again."That was different," Jordan protested, though his smile remained. "I had a paper due, and Professor Martinez had that ridiculous attendance policy. You literally carried me back to my dorm and made me soup from a can while lecturing me about self-care." He paused, his expression growing more serious as he looked at Spencer in the dim lamplight. "You've always taken better care of me than I take care of myself. Even back then, when we barely knew each other, you just stepped up without being asked. I don't think I ever properly thanked you for that."

Spencer felt his cheeks warm and was grateful for the low lighting that might hide his blush. The weight of Jordan's gratitude felt both wonderful and painful, a reminder of how much he cared and how impossible it was to express the true depth of those feelings. He had always been the caretaker in their friendship, partly because it came naturally to him, but mostly because loving Jordan meant wanting to protect him from every discomfort, no matter how small.

"You don't need to thank me," Spencer said quietly. "That's what friends do for each other." The word 'friends' felt hollow in his mouth, a deliberate understatement that had become his shield over the years. Every time he said it, he was reminding both of them of the boundaries that existed between them, even as his heart screamed against those limitations.

Jordan was quiet for a long moment, studying Spencer's face with an intensity that made Spencer want to squirm in his chair. There was something different in Jordan's expression, a thoughtfulness that went beyond fever-induced confusion. When he finally spoke, his voice was soft and uncertain in a way that was completely unlike his usual confident tone.

"Spencer, can I ask you something? And will you give me an honest answer, not just what you think I want to hear?" The seriousness of Jordan's request made Spencer's stomach clench with anxiety. In four years of friendship, Jordan had never prefaced a question quite like this, and Spencer couldn't imagine what might be coming. His mind raced through possibilities, most of them involving his carefully hidden feelings being somehow discovered.

"Of course," Spencer managed, though his voice came out slightly strained. He gripped the arms of his chair, preparing himself for whatever confession or confrontation was about to unfold. Jordan shifted in the bed, propping himself up on his elbow so he could face Spencer directly, despite the obvious effort it took in his weakened state.

"Have you ever been in love? I mean really, completely, can't-think-about-anything-else in love?" Jordan's question was so different from what Spencer had expected that for a moment he couldn't process it. The irony was almost cruel – here was Jordan, the object of Spencer's deepest and most secret affections, asking about love while Spencer sat beside his bed, heart full of everything he couldn't say.

Spencer's mouth went dry, and he found himself staring at his hands rather than meeting Jordan's eyes. How could he answer honestly without revealing everything? How could he lie to Jordan when his friend had specifically asked for honesty? The silence stretched between them, filled with the weight of everything Spencer wanted to say and couldn't.

"Why are you asking?" Spencer finally managed, buying himself time to think. It was a coward's response, deflecting instead of answering, but he was too afraid of where the truth might lead them. Jordan's expression didn't change, but something flickered in his eyes that Spencer couldn't quite identify.

"Because I think I might be," Jordan said quietly, and Spencer felt his heart stop entirely. The pain was immediate and sharp, jealousy and heartbreak combining into something that made it hard to breathe. Of course Jordan was in love with someone. Of course there was someone Spencer didn't know about, someone who had captured Jordan's attention in a way that Spencer never could. He forced himself to ask the question that would only hurt more to hear answered.

"With who?" The words came out rougher than Spencer intended, and he cleared his throat, trying to sound like a supportive friend rather than someone whose world was crumbling. Jordan was still looking at him intently, and Spencer realized that his friend was waiting for something, some response that Spencer wasn't understanding.

"That's what I'm trying to figure out," Jordan said, and there was a vulnerability in his voice that Spencer had rarely heard before. "It's someone I've known for a long time, someone who's been right there all along, but I've been too stupid or too scared to see it clearly. And now, with graduation and everything changing, I can't stop thinking about what I might be losing if I don't say something."

Spencer felt like he was drowning, trying to process Jordan's words while his own emotions threatened to overwhelm him. The rational part of his mind was telling him to be a good friend, to encourage Jordan to pursue whoever had captured his heart, but every other part of him was screaming in protest. He had become an expert at hiding his feelings, at playing the role of the supportive best friend, but this felt like more than he could bear.

"Maybe you should tell them," Spencer heard himself say, the words coming from some automated part of his brain that knew how to respond appropriately even when his heart was breaking. "If you really think you're in love, and you're worried about losing them, maybe honesty is better than regret." Even as he said it, Spencer recognized the hypocrisy of his advice, given his own years of carefully maintained silence.

Jordan was quiet for a long moment, his fever-bright eyes never leaving Spencer's face. There was something searching in his expression, as if he was looking for clues to a puzzle that Spencer couldn't understand. The silence felt charged with unspoken words, and Spencer found himself holding his breath without knowing why.

"What if it changes everything?" Jordan asked finally. "What if saying something ruins the best friendship I've ever had? What if they don't feel the same way, and suddenly everything becomes awkward and weird, and I lose them completely?" The pain in Jordan's voice was evident, and despite his own heartbreak, Spencer felt his protective instincts kick in. This was Jordan hurting, and Spencer's first impulse was always to try to fix whatever was causing that pain, even when he was the one who would be hurt in the process.

"Then they weren't really your friend to begin with," Spencer said, forcing conviction into his voice that he didn't entirely feel. "Real friendship survives honesty, even when it's complicated. And anyone would be lucky to have you love them." The last sentence came out more intensely than Spencer intended, carrying weight that he immediately wanted to take back. Jordan's eyes widened slightly, and Spencer realized he had revealed more than he meant to.

"Spencer," Jordan said softly, and there was something in the way he said Spencer's name that made Spencer's heart race with a mixture of hope and terror. Jordan was struggling to sit up fully, his movements still sluggish from fever but determined. "Spencer, look at me. Please." Spencer had been staring at his hands again, but Jordan's tone made him lift his eyes reluctantly. What he saw in Jordan's face was an expression he had never seen before, tender and uncertain and full of something that Spencer didn't dare to interpret.

"The person I think I'm in love with," Jordan continued, his voice barely above a whisper, "is sitting in that chair right now, looking like he wants to run away rather than hear what I'm trying to say." Spencer's world tilted entirely off its axis, Jordan's words hitting him like a physical force that left him speechless and staring. This couldn't be happening. This couldn't be real. Jordan couldn't be saying what Spencer thought he was saying, not after four years of Spencer convincing himself that his feelings were one-sided and impossible.

"Jordan, you have a fever," Spencer managed weakly, grasping for any explanation that didn't require him to believe that his deepest wish might actually be coming true. "You're not thinking clearly. You should rest, and we can talk about this when you're feeling better." It was a desperate attempt to give both of them an escape route, a way to pretend this conversation never happened if Jordan regretted it later.

But Jordan shook his head firmly, more alert and focused than he had been all evening. "My fever isn't that high, and I'm not delirious. I've been thinking about this for months, Spencer. Maybe longer. Every time you take care of me when I'm sick, every time you listen to me complain about bad dates, every time you just show up exactly when I need you most." Jordan's voice grew stronger as he continued, as if finally speaking the words was giving him energy. "I kept thinking it was just friendship, just gratitude for having someone who actually cares. But it's not, is it? It's never been just friendship, not really."Chapter 2

Spencer felt as if the world had shifted into slow motion, every sound in the room amplified while his thoughts moved through thick honey. Jordan's words hung in the air between them, and Spencer found himself cataloging every detail of this moment – the way the lamplight cast warm shadows across Jordan's face, the faint sound of late-night traffic outside the apartment window, the smell of Jordan's cologne mixed with the medicinal scent of fever reducers. He had imagined variations of this conversation countless times over the years, usually late at night when sleep eluded him and hope felt like a luxury he could briefly afford. But none of his imagined scenarios had prepared him for the reality of Jordan's confession, or for the way his own body seemed to have forgotten how to perform basic functions like breathing and thinking coherently.

"I don't understand," Spencer said finally, though part of him understood perfectly and was terrified by the implications. "You've never... I mean, you date women. You've always dated women." It was a weak protest, but Spencer's mind was grasping for any foothold in familiar territory. Jordan's dating history had been one of the constants that Spencer had used to maintain his emotional distance, a reminder that his feelings were fundamentally impossible and therefore safe to harbor in secret.

Jordan's smile was gentle and slightly sad, as if he had expected this response. "I've dated women because it was easy, because it was expected, because I thought that's what I was supposed to do. But Spencer, none of those relationships ever felt like this. None of them ever made me want to be a better person, or made me feel like I was home just by being near someone." He paused, running a hand through his disheveled hair in a gesture Spencer recognized as nervous uncertainty. "I think I've been in love with you for years and just too scared or too stupid to admit it to myself, let alone to you."

The honesty in Jordan's voice was devastating in its simplicity, and Spencer felt tears prick at the corners of his eyes. This was everything he had wanted to hear and everything he had convinced himself was impossible, and the collision of hope and disbelief was overwhelming. He stood up abruptly from the chair, needing movement to process the enormity of what was happening, and began pacing the small space beside Jordan's bed like a caged animal.

"This is crazy," Spencer said, though he wasn't sure if he meant the situation or his reaction to it. "Four years, Jordan. We've been friends for four years, and you're telling me this now? Tonight? When you're sick and we're both emotional about graduation and everything changing?" Even as he said it, Spencer knew he was being unfair, looking for reasons to doubt rather than reasons to believe, but self-protection had become such an ingrained habit that he couldn't seem to stop himself.

Jordan watched Spencer pace with patient eyes, and when he spoke again, his voice was calm and certain in a way that cut through Spencer's panic. "I'm telling you this now because almost losing you made me realize I couldn't live with the regret of never trying. When I got sick tonight and you just immediately took care of me, no questions asked, no hesitation, it hit me how much I've come to depend on you being in my life. And then I started thinking about what happens after graduation, about the possibility that we might drift apart or end up in different cities, and I couldn't bear the thought of wondering 'what if' for the rest of my life."

Spencer stopped pacing and turned to face Jordan directly, searching his friend's face for any sign of fever-induced confusion or misplaced gratitude. What he saw instead was a clarity and determination that he had rarely seen from Jordan, even when he was completely healthy. This wasn't a sick person talking nonsense; this was Jordan being more honest and vulnerable than Spencer had ever seen him, and that realization was both thrilling and terrifying.

"You're not losing me," Spencer said quietly, addressing the fear he could hear underlying Jordan's confession. "Graduation doesn't change the fact that you're the most important person in my life. You're not getting rid of me just because we're not living in the same college town anymore." The words came out more intensely than Spencer intended, carrying years of his own fears about their friendship surviving the transition to adult life.

Jordan's expression softened, and he extended his hand toward Spencer in a gesture that was both invitation and plea. "Come here. Please. I can't have this conversation with you pacing around like you're planning an escape route." Spencer hesitated for a moment, knowing that accepting Jordan's hand would be crossing a line they couldn't uncross, but ultimately unable to deny the request. He moved back to the bed and sat on the edge, close enough that their knees were almost touching, and allowed Jordan to take his hand.

The contact was electric in a way that Spencer had spent years trying to ignore, Jordan's fingers warm and slightly rough against his own. They had touched casually hundreds of times over the years – brief hugs, playful shoves, the kind of physical contact that came naturally in close friendship – but this felt different, charged with intention and possibility that made Spencer's heart race.

"Tell me what you're thinking," Jordan said softly, his thumb tracing over Spencer's knuckles in a gesture that was tender and intimate and completely new between them. "I just laid my heart out for you, and you look like you're about to bolt. I need to know what's going on in that head of yours." The request was fair, but Spencer found himself struggling to articulate the chaos of emotions and thoughts swirling through his mind. How do you explain four years of hidden longing, of careful emotional management, of convinced impossibility suddenly being challenged by reality?

"I'm thinking that this feels like a dream," Spencer admitted, his voice barely audible. "I'm thinking that I've imagined you saying these words so many times that I'm not sure I can trust that it's really happening. And I'm terrified that I'm going to wake up tomorrow and find out that you were just sick and emotional and didn't mean any of it." The vulnerability in his own words surprised him, but Jordan's hand in his gave him courage to continue being honest.

"I'm also thinking," Spencer continued, meeting Jordan's eyes directly for the first time since the conversation began, "that I've been in love with you since sophomore year, and I convinced myself that it was hopeless and one-sided, and I learned to live with that because having you as a friend was better than not having you at all. But if you're telling me that maybe it wasn't one-sided, if you're saying that maybe you've felt it too, then everything I thought I knew about us is wrong."

Jordan's eyes widened at Spencer's confession, and his grip on Spencer's hand tightened as if he was afraid Spencer might disappear. "Sophomore year? Spencer, that's when I started noticing things too, little things that I told myself were just friendship but felt like more. The way you'd bring me coffee during finals week without being asked, the way you remembered things I told you in passing, the way you looked at me sometimes when you thought I wasn't paying attention." Jordan's voice grew more animated as he spoke, despite his lingering illness, as if years of suppressed feelings were finally finding expression.

"There was this moment during spring break junior year, when everyone else had gone home and we were the only ones left on campus," Jordan continued, his eyes never leaving Spencer's face. "We spent the whole week together, just hanging out, watching movies, talking about everything and nothing. And I remember thinking that I had never been happier, that this was what contentment felt like. But then everyone came back, and life got busy again, and I convinced myself I was just lonely and reading too much into a good friendship."

Spencer remembered that week vividly, remembered feeling like he was getting a glimpse of what it might be like to be with Jordan as more than friends, only to watch that intimacy fade back into their usual dynamic when other people returned to their lives. He had spent months afterward wondering if he had imagined the shift in energy between them, the moments when conversation had felt charged with possibility, the way they had gravitated toward each other's space without conscious thought.

"I remember that week," Spencer said, surprised by the steadiness in his own voice. "I remember thinking that if I could have any week of my life on repeat forever, it would be that one. Just us, just easy and comfortable and perfect. But I also remember being convinced that you couldn't possibly be feeling the same things I was feeling, so I never said anything." The admission felt both liberating and terrifying, years of careful emotional management being dismantled in real time.

Jordan brought Spencer's hand to his lips and pressed a soft kiss to his knuckles, a gesture so tender that Spencer felt his breath catch in his throat. "We're both idiots," Jordan said with a weak laugh. "Two people in love with each other, both convinced it was impossible, both too scared to risk the friendship by being honest. We could have saved ourselves years of frustration if either one of us had been brave enough to speak up."

The word 'love' hung in the air between them, no longer theoretical or one-sided but mutual and acknowledged, and Spencer felt something in his chest loosen that he hadn't even realized was tight. This was real. Jordan loved him back. The impossibility that had defined Spencer's emotional life for years was dissolving, replaced by a future that suddenly seemed full of potential he had never allowed himself to imagine.

"So what happens now?" Spencer asked, aware that they were at a turning point that would define everything that came after. They couldn't go back to being just friends, not after this conversation, not after finally acknowledging the feelings that had been simmering beneath the surface of their relationship for years. But Spencer also knew that love didn't automatically solve the practical complications of two lives that had been moving in parallel rather than together.

Jordan was quiet for a long moment, clearly thinking through the same questions that were racing through Spencer's mind. When he spoke, his voice was thoughtful and careful, as if he was testing each word before committing to it. "I think what happens now is that we figure it out together, the same way we've figured everything else out for the past four years. We're both starting graduate programs in the fall – mine at University of Florida, yours at Florida State. That's two hours apart, which isn't ideal, but it's manageable. We make it work because what we have is worth making work."

The practicality of Jordan's response was both reassuring and overwhelming. Spencer had spent so long thinking of his feelings as impossible that he had never allowed himself to consider the logistics of an actual relationship with Jordan. The idea that they could make it work, that love might be enough to bridge the gap between their separate lives, was intoxicating and scary in equal measure.

"Two hours apart," Spencer repeated, testing how the words felt. "Weekend visits, phone calls, making plans around each other's schedules. That's not how I imagined starting a relationship." He paused, then added with a slight smile, "Not that I allowed myself to imagine starting a relationship with you very often, but when I did, it usually involved us being in the same city."

Jordan laughed, the sound slightly hoarse but genuinely amused. "Since when has anything about us gone according to plan? We became best friends because you happened to be the only person in our dorm who knew how to operate the ancient coffee maker in the common kitchen. We survived Professor Martinez's Victorian Literature class because you agreed to be my study partner even though I was clearly in over my head. We've been figuring things out as we go along for four years – this is just the next thing to figure out."

Spencer found himself smiling despite his lingering uncertainty, Jordan's optimism and confidence slowly working to ease his anxiety. This was the Jordan he had fallen in love with – the one who approached challenges with determination and humor, who made complicated things seem manageable through sheer force of positive thinking. If Jordan believed they could make a relationship work despite the geographical distance and the newness of everything between them, maybe Spencer could believe it too.

"Besides," Jordan continued, his voice taking on a slightly teasing tone that Spencer recognized from years of friendship, "you're forgetting that I'm incredibly charming and irresistible. Two hours apart just means you'll appreciate me more when we're together. Absence makes the heart grow fonder and all that." The joke was classic Jordan, using humor to diffuse tension while also fishing for reassurance, and Spencer felt a rush of affection for the familiar dynamic even as everything else between them was changing.

"Your ego is really something else," Spencer said, but his tone was fond rather than critical. "Here you are, sick as a dog, confessing your feelings in the middle of the night, and you're still managing to be cocky about your irresistible charm." He shook his head in mock exasperation, but inside he was marveling at how natural this felt, how easily they were slipping into a new dynamic that incorporated both their long-standing friendship and their newly acknowledged romantic feelings.

Jordan's expression grew more serious, though his eyes remained warm and focused on Spencer's face. "I'm not being cocky, I'm being hopeful. The humid air of Tallahassee clung to Spencer's skin like a damp shirt as he walked across the campus quad, his worn sneakers making soft sounds against the brick pathway. The late afternoon sun filtered through the canopy of oak trees, casting dancing shadows that seemed to mirror the restless feeling in his chest. At twenty-three, Spencer had grown accustomed to the weight of secrets, but some secrets felt heavier than others, especially when they involved matters of the heart.

"Spencer, wait up!" The familiar voice made him turn, and there was Jordan, jogging to catch up with that easy smile that had been Spencer's undoing since their freshman year. Jordan's dark hair was tousled from running, and his green eyes held that perpetual spark of mischief that Spencer had fallen in love with somewhere between late-night study sessions and early morning coffee runs.

"You're going to be late for your own graduation party," Jordan said, slightly breathless as he fell into step beside Spencer. Their friendship had been the most natural thing in the world, built on shared laughter, comfortable silences, and an understanding that went deeper than words. But for Spencer, it had become something more complicated, something that lived in the spaces between what was said and what remained carefully hidden.

"I'm not sure I'm in the mood for celebrating," Spencer replied, adjusting the strap of his messenger bag. The leather was worn smooth from years of use, a gift from his adoptive parents when he'd started college. They'd been supportive of his studies in literature, though Spencer sometimes caught them exchanging glances when they thought he wasn't looking, as if they were keeping their own secrets.

Jordan stopped walking and grabbed Spencer's arm gently. "Hey, what's going on? You've been weird all week. This is supposed to be our big moment – we made it through four years of college without killing each other or flunking out. That deserves at least a beer and some terrible karaoke."

Spencer looked at Jordan's hand on his arm and felt that familiar flutter in his stomach. How do you tell your best friend that somewhere along the way, friendship had transformed into something that kept you awake at night? How do you explain that every casual touch feels like electricity, that every laugh shared feels like a small piece of heaven, that you've been living with this secret love for so long it's become part of your DNA?

"It's nothing," Spencer lied, the words tasting bitter on his tongue. "Just thinking about what comes next, you know? Everything's changing."

Jordan's expression softened, and he moved his hand to Spencer's shoulder. "Change isn't always bad. Besides, we're not going anywhere. You're stuck with me, remember? We made a pact sophomore year – best friends for life, through thick and thin, through bad relationships and career disasters."

The mention of relationships sent a small stab through Spencer's heart. Jordan had dated casually throughout college, nothing serious, but each new person had been a reminder of what Spencer couldn't have. He'd become an expert at being the supportive friend, offering advice and listening to stories about dates while dying a little inside each time.

"Right," Spencer managed, forcing a smile. "The pact."

They resumed walking toward downtown Tallahassee, where their favorite bar was hosting what Jordan had dubbed their "freedom celebration." The streets were alive with the energy of a college town in late spring, students spilling out of restaurants and cafes, everyone seeming to move with purpose and excitement about the future. Spencer envied their certainty.

"You know what I was thinking about today?" Jordan said, his hands shoved deep in his pockets. "Remember freshman year when you got food poisoning from that sketchy taco truck, and I stayed up all night taking care of you? You were so embarrassed, kept apologizing for ruining my weekend."

Spencer remembered. He remembered Jordan bringing him ginger ale and sitting on the edge of his dorm room bed, talking quietly about everything and nothing while Spencer's stomach settled. He remembered thinking, even through the nausea, that this was what love felt like – not the dramatic, sweeping kind from movies, but the quiet, steady kind that showed up with medicine and stayed through the messy parts.

"I remember you making fun of me for being dramatic," Spencer said.

"I wasn't making fun of you. I was trying to distract you. There's a difference." Jordan bumped his shoulder against Spencer's. "That was when I knew we were going to be real friends. Not just dorm room proximity friends or study group friends, but the kind of friends who see each other at your worst and stick around anyway."

Spencer's chest tightened. Jordan meant it as a compliment, but it felt like a gentle reminder of the boundaries between them. Friends. Always friends.

The bar was crowded when they arrived, filled with familiar faces from their literature classes and a handful of people from Jordan's philosophy major. Spencer had always been more introverted, content to let Jordan be the social butterfly while he observed from the edges. Tonight felt no different, except for the underlying current of melancholy that Spencer couldn't shake.

"Spencer!" Lisa from their Victorian Literature seminar waved them over to a corner booth. "We saved you guys seats. Jordan said you might actually show up tonight instead of hiding in the library."

"Very funny," Spencer said, sliding into the booth. Jordan settled beside him, close enough that their thighs touched, and Spencer had to concentrate on not reading anything into the casual contact.

The conversation flowed around them – post-graduation plans, job prospects, speculation about professors they'd never have to see again. Spencer contributed when spoken to directly but found himself mostly listening, watching Jordan animated and happy, laughing at stories and adding his own. This was Jordan in his element, surrounded by people who enjoyed his company, unaware of the quiet intensity of Spencer's gaze.

"What about you, Spencer?" The question came from Mike, a guy from Jordan's philosophy classes who Spencer had never particularly warmed to. "Any big plans now that you're free from academic tyranny?"

"Teaching," Spencer said simply. "I start a graduate program in the fall, working toward becoming a professor."

"Following in someone's footsteps?" Mike asked, and something about his tone made Spencer look up sharply.

"Not really," Spencer replied carefully. "I just love literature. Want to share that with students someday."

Jordan jumped in, sensing Spencer's discomfort. "Spencer's going to be one of those professors students remember forever. The kind who actually makes you think about books instead of just memorizing themes for tests."

The warmth in Jordan's voice made Spencer's heart skip, but before he could respond, Jordan suddenly went pale and pressed a hand to his forehead.

"You okay?" Spencer asked immediately, his attention fully focused on his friend.

"Yeah, just... suddenly feel really hot. And my head is pounding." Jordan's voice sounded strained, different from his usual easy tone.

Spencer reached over and pressed the back of his hand to Jordan's forehead. Jordan's skin was burning up, fever heat that made Spencer's stomach drop with worry.

"You're burning up. We should get you home."

Without waiting for Jordan's protest, Spencer was already sliding out of the booth, his protective instincts overriding any social awkwardness. He'd seen Jordan sick before, but this felt different – the sudden onset, the way Jordan's usually bright eyes had gone glassy and unfocused. The bar's noise and warmth suddenly felt oppressive, and Spencer could see that Jordan was struggling to maintain his composure in front of their friends.
